ygData.subject: New paper: A Hybridization of Deep Learning and Neuroevolution for Visual Control
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi all, Andreas Precht Poulsen, Mark Thorhauge, Mikkel Hvilshj Funch, and myself are happy to announce our new CIG paper titled DLNE: A Hybridization of Deep

Subject: New paper: A Hybridization of Deep Learning and Neuroevolution for
 Visual Control
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=360532607; y=LqJwRnqMUdf9Dry9zl5fgrFeGmlmgzTvHTab8C7BnSMNq15frCotSWM
X-Yahoo-Profile: sebastian.risi
From: Sebastian Risi <sebastian.risi@...>

Hi all,

Andreas Precht Poulsen, Mark Thorhauge, Mikkel Hvilshj Funch, and
=
myself are happy to announce our new CIG paper titled "DLNE: A
Hybridizatio=
n of Deep Learning and Neuroevolution for Visual Control".

In this paper w=
e combine a deep neural network that is responsible to
identify the positio=
n of a target in an FPS setting with an ANN
evolved by NEAT. While the comb=
ination of the two techniques is not
perfect (see the example video of the =
 at:
https://youtu.be/daFvJa90f8Y), the hybrid approach performs reasonably=

well and is in fact able to aim&shoot based on the raw pixel
representatio=
n of 256=C3=97256=C3=973 images. We believe the paper might allow
neuroevol=
ution to scale to more complex domains by directly exploiting
the advances =
of recent deep learning approaches.

PDF: http://sebastianrisi.com/wp-conte=
nt/uploads/poulsen_cig17.pdf

Abstract: This paper investigates the potenti=
al of combining deep
learning and neuroevolution to create a bot for a simp=
le first person
shooter (FPS) game capable of aiming and shooting based on
=
high-dimensional raw pixel input. The deep learning component is
responsibl=
e for visual recognition and translating raw pixels to
compact feature repr=
esentations, while the evolving network takes
those features as inputs to i=
nfer actions. Two types of feature
representations are evaluated in terms o=
f (1) how precise they allow
the deep network to recognize the position of =
the enemy, (2) their
effect on evolution, and (3) how well they allow the d=
eep network and
evolved network to interface with each other. Overall, the =
results
suggest that combining deep learning and neuroevolution in a hybrid=

approach is a promising research direction that could make complex
visual =
domains directly accessible to networks trained through
evolution.

Best,
S=
ebastian

-- 
Dr. Sebastian Risi
Associate Professor
IT University of Copen=
hagen, Room 5D12
